item.title: Final Project - Sad Plot Made Better 3.0
item.description: Set global options Load libraries Read in data quant <- read_csv("https://gist.githubusercontent.com/sschlesinger/44ec0c892ce0bf0d78e750bc78e2aef7/raw/bba5617841b28de26a569c5a0dd10d2cd7933fc9/TendonQuant.csv") ## Parsed with column specification: ## cols( ## Mouse = col_character(), ## Stage = col_character(), ## Dapi = col_double(), ## Edu = col_double(), ## CSA = col_integer(), ## Length = col_integer() ## ) glimpse(quant) ## Observations: 25 ## Variables: 6 ## $ Mouse <chr> "EH89-2", "EH89-4", "EH89-5", "ER93-1", "FI01-1", "LW02... ## $ Stage <chr> "E14.5", "E14.5", "E14.5", "E14.5", "E16.5", "E16.

item.title: About
item.description: Saundra Schlesinger is a PhD candidate currently studying tendon development. As an undergraduate she attended Arizona State University where she studied the role of hypoxia on insect physiology in the lab of Dr. Jon Harrison. She graduated in 2010 with a degree in Genetics, Cell, and Developmental Biology. She then worked as a research technician in the lab of Dr. Peter Chen at the University of Washington where she investigated the role of the protein Syndecan-1 in the progression of wound healing, influenza infection, and lung cancer.

item.title: 01 - Sad Plot Made Better
item.description: Call In Libraries and Data library(tidyverse) ## -- Attaching packages ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ tidyverse 1.2.1 -- ## v ggplot2 2.2.1 v purrr 0.2.4 ## v tibble 1.4.2 v dplyr 0.7.5 ## v tidyr 0.8.1 v stringr 1.3.1 ## v readr 1.1.1 v forcats 0.3.0 ## -- Conflicts --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- tidyverse_conflicts() -- ## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## x dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(readr) library(babynames) library(stringr) Add column of first letters baby_letters <- babynames %>% mutate(first_letter=str_sub(name, 1,1)) Add up proportion for each letter by year + sex

item.title: 02 - Sad Plot Made Better
item.description: CHALLENGE #3 #Read in new dataset, post-1981 males only with post-IFOCE TRUE/FALSE column hdm_affil <- read_csv(("https://gist.githubusercontent.com/sschlesinger/3a846e9f56eb6603471cce60181ac2c8/raw/3a2e4039f5bf958344ce5a8db97a72576624c57a/hot_dog_contest_with_affiliation.csv"), col_types = cols( affiliated = col_factor(levels = NULL), gender = col_factor(levels = NULL) )) %>% mutate(post_ifoce = year >= 1997) %>% filter(year >= 1981 & gender == "male") glimpse(hdm_affil) ## Observations: 37 ## Variables: 6 ## $ year <int> 2017, 2016, 2015, 2014, 2013, 2012, 2011, 2010, 200... ## $ gender <fct> male, male, male, male, male, male, male, male, mal.

item.title: 03 - Sad Plot Made Better
item.description: library(readr) moma <- read_csv("http://bit.ly/cs631-moma") ## Parsed with column specification: ## cols( ## .default = col_character(), ## artist_birth_year = col_integer(), ## artist_death_year = col_double(), ## num_artists = col_integer(), ## n_female_artists = col_integer(), ## n_male_artists = col_integer(), ## year_acquired = col_double(), ## year_created = col_integer(), ## depth_cm = col_double(), ## height_cm = col_double(), ## width_cm = col_double(), ## purchase = col_logical(), ## gift = col_logical(), ## exchange = col_logical() ## ) ## See spec(.

item.title: 04 - Sad Plot Made Better
item.description: library(gapminder) library(tidyverse) ## -- Attaching packages ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ tidyverse 1.2.1 -- ## v ggplot2 2.2.1 v purrr 0.2.4 ## v tibble 1.4.2 v dplyr 0.7.5 ## v tidyr 0.8.1 v stringr 1.3.1 ## v readr 1.1.1 v forcats 0.3.0 ## -- Conflicts --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- tidyverse_conflicts() -- ## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## x dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(readr) Gapminder Challenge Pick at least two of the tasks below from the task menu and approach each with a table and figure.
